title: Do Western Europeans look down on Eastern Europeans? - Quora
tags: What Do Europeans Think of X

response.answer_text: The answer here in the UK is most definitely yes, I am in an interesting position being half of each (I know many Polish do not like Eastern European and prefer central European, but in the UK they see us as Eastern European), so I can offer my experiences and observations having good knowledge of Eastern Europe, having lived in Russia, with Bulgarian family and of Polish descent living in London England. My background as a psychological clinician also helps. Cultural Hierarchy The way in which Western Europeans tend to look down on Eastern or Central Europeans is often by reference to a sort of hierarchy of culture in which the West naturally frames itself as more advanced. The idea that is usually promoted subtly within the West is that Eastern Europeans are thuggish and rube-like, more backward and uncivilised than Western Europeans, and either are not quite cultured or ‘white’ enough, involved in crime and benefit fraud (This is the view often promoted by the Right) or alternatively that they are ‘too white’ and possess a sort of essentialised racism and pathological antisemitism which means that they cannot be trusted to make their own decisions, and need to be paternally educated out of the sins of nationalism, religion, traditional gender roles and dislike of communism (the view of the Left). Essentially neither the left or right in Western Europe can fit Eastern Europeans into their political schema and so there is a judgement on both sides as a result of this. It is interesting analysing this in comparison to some other ethnic groups because if you were to draw from the examples of some other marginalised groups you would expect racism and cultural chauvinism towards Eastern Europeans to be mainly a ‘right wing’ phenomenon, in reality (much like recent developments in anti-semitism) the racism which is encountered is from the Left and Right in almost equal measure. Recently the disdain towards the East seems even to be more weighted towards the left in the UK as the Visegrad group and Russia becomes more politically hostile to left-liberal values. Multiculturalism, History and Snobbery What is very weird about the way that Western Europe looks down on Eastern Europe is the confounding of history around the question and politics of race, and the leveraging of it in a way which serves the sense of superiority of Western commentators - the use of the ideology of multiculturalism employed in this way (as a yardstick to justify subtle racism and cultural chauvinism against the East ) seems paradoxical and perverse but unfortunately this is very much the case. for instance with Poland the accusation from the west of anti-semitism is constant; even though the mass racial genocide of the Holocaust was caused by a western European country, and the most attacks on Jews today currently occur in France and Germany: the idea of anti semitism as a essential character trait is associated with the Pole or Ukrainian and not the German, who by contrast is seen as having slipped into some sort of unfortunate yet temporary psychosis. Borat speaks with Polish words in expressing his fear of Jews and Gypsies, Obama talks about Polish death camps. It is interesting to watch this phenomena take place. Similarly, often the racial homogeneity of much of Eastern Europe is brought up by Western European media as a justification for judgement, as if this was a sign of the Easts cultural backwardness, ignoring the historical context as to why originally such a multicultural mixture in countries like the UK or France first emerged - (colonisation and race based slavery). One of the most obvious instances of this was during the Euro 2012 football tournament. This was held in Poland and Ukraine and the coverage in terms of television was really instructive in that the dormant views of Eastern Europeans were suddenly being propelled onto screen and page at every turn. A sort of hysteria was whipped up which I had never seen before in my life. A number of footballers who reside in Western Europe, notably Sol Campbell and Patrick Viera were saying things like “if you are black and you go over there (Poland/Ukraine) you will be coming back in a coffin” - (this is an actual quote from Campbell, humorously satirised in the video below). Viera complained at being ‘stared at’, not thinking that perhaps this might be because he was Patrick Viera, the 6 foot 3 world famous footballer, but instead implied that each stare was an indicator of the dark hearts of racial savagery that beat beneath the breast of every Slav. This was amazing for me, the idea that the Eastern Europeans seethe with murderous anger at the sight of an outsider, but I realised for the first time that this image of the Slavic ‘other’ as some kind of Nazi peasant is more prevalent than I had first thought.  Nationalism A similar, related example of disdain and judgement towards Eastern Europe from the West involves the idea of national pride, nationalism or patriotism. Western European countries frame the relatively high levels of national pride and expressions of love for country as being worrying signs of the decline of democracy, and slipping towards inevitable fascism. Even when nationalist governments are voted for democratically, this is seen as indicators of the backwardness of a people who are not quite ready for democracy yet, and the governments of these countries are portrayed in western media only slightly better than North Korea or the Syrian regime. There are many historical reasons why this is a false comparison to draw, partly due to the fact that Western Europe did not experience the same attacks on national identity and sovereignty from hegemonic imperialists such as Communism, Prussia, Nazis, Russian empire, Ottomans etc. so there is a sense amongst these relatively recently freed countries that now that national independence has been won, it needs to be vigorously protected. In contrast when your culture is hegemonic, as Western Europe has been through much of modern history (and still currently is), there is of course no need to establish a sense of independence or national pride in the same way, because there is much less real existential threat to your nation and culture. In the West, therefore, national pride is seen as a sign of backwardness, a cardinal sin and a regression back to colonial times, which of course Eastern Europe never took part in. Eastern Euros are therefore framed as being backward and uncultured, even potential Nazis, for holding these beliefs. This disdain for patriotism is supported culturally by middle and upper-middle class trends in Western academia around postcolonial studies and other areas in the humanities influenced by Marxism etc. which are less popular in the East in response to their pragmatic reality. whereas in contrast in a lot of the time in the UK especially, patriotism is associated with ‘lower’ castes like the white working class and people who live outside of major cities. As Western Europe sees itself as the harbinger of a glorious future, any attempt to draw a distinction from the advance of this global liberalism is seen as a threat and again as a sort of reactionary backwardness, and failure of the beastly East to accept progress. Similarly, refusals to accept encroachments on national sovereignty are framed as being indicators of racism, such as has recently occurred with the issue around migrant quotas. Schrodinger's Migrant A more simplistic and easily recognisable way in which Eastern Europeans are judged and discriminated against in the UK is through employing what has been termed Schrodingers Migrant. Named after the famous experiment with the cat in the box which could either be alive or dead and you never know until you actually look in the box, one can never know if this type of migrant will be stealing your jobs or scrounging from your benefits, or miraculously doing both at the same time in a state of quantum uncertainty until the collapse of the state vector one way or the other. Nigel Farage spectacularly drew on this kind of stereotype by blaming Polish people for causing traffic on the M4 motorway. This image of a sort of polluting human plague shifts each time a new wave of migrant comes through, it was first the Polish (job stealing benefit cheats), then the Romanians (gypsy benefit cheats) and then Bulgarian (pickpocket benefit cheats) and probably will go through the entire continental selection. A good example of this type of stereotyping is the character of Czernobog in American Gods, obviously this is an American program but there is much in this figure that I recognised in how the UK portrays Eastern Europeans. Brutish, violent, uncultured, unclean, works in a abattoir, smokes unceasingly.  I could keep the examples coming in terms of this question but some of the issues around attitudes of religion, cultural values and gender roles would be quite repetitive. A lot of this is quite subtle as well, we are not a trendy minority and often the judgement is placed on the back of progressive values and therefore has an air of moral righteousness.

upvoters.user_id: Thomas de La Marnierre (トマ・サレ)

response.answer_text: In the UK, I don’t really think so. My partner was born and raised in Hungary — which is technically Central Europe, but of course is to the East of Western Europe. In the past, after the fall of the USSR, we had a stereotype of Eastern Europeans. They were naive, poor, often over-qualified but badly dressed. Sacha Baron-Cohen’s “Borat”, in a nutshell. That stereotype no longer exists. Well, it exists, but isn’t common and widespread in the way that it used to be. Attitudes to Eastern Europeans now are very mixed; positive and negative stereotypes mix together, and most people I think just take everyone as an individual. I notice that among very right-wing people, there is an increasing reverence for Hungary and Poland, and an envy of them. They were asked to accept refugees, and they said “no”. Hungary also defunded gender studies. Left-wing people, on the other hand, are somewhat convinced that Hungary and Poland are now ruled by evil dictatorships. Working class people may sometimes resent competition from Polish plumbers in particular, which is not the same as looking down on them. Middle class people are liable to admire the competence of Polish workers in the UK. Men often admire the beauty of Eastern European women. Eastern European gangs are a problem in some parts of the UK, influencing attitudes there, but are seemingly absent from other parts. There are certain appearances that people associate with gangs, I think; not the typical appearance of an Eastern European. You can’t please all of the people all of the time.

Yes, and it’s unfortunate. But the reason is what scares me. A while ago some Romanians raped someone. All the titles said “Romanian men raped…”. Awesome, I don’t condone rape, even if I’m Romanian myself. Well, have the same crime done by someone of Pakistan or muslim, or some other protected origin. You will see that most publications do not disclose his country of origin and background. Well, you don’t want to appear racist, do you? Also, the comments are closed. Well, I’m not saying that my people are saints. I’m just saying that the media over represents them when they do something bad, and under represents the other minorities, so most people get the wrong idea. We are mostly white, Christian, and we’re not protected by the PC culture.

In Spain they don’t -generally speaking. except for some characteristic groups as Romanian gypsies or Albanian gypsies. On the other hand, I was surprised at seeing UK citizens having got a very bad opinion about Russians and Poles. I’m speaking about my experience in UK. So it’s not a scientific approach. But I met there many people thinking Russian people are unfriendly and bad ( maybe too many James Bond movies?) And they despise Polish people in an incredible racist way. Comments such us “There are too many Poles” or jokes about them aren’t uncommon. These would be unacceptable in UK if referring to African British citizens or any other ethnic group. It’s incredible they don’t realize that,  Anti-Polish sentiment - Wikipedia

Well, who cares what Western Europeans think? If their collective achievement through the history has boiled down to the permanent loss of control and dominion within their own countries, then any claim of superiority towards the East Europeans is irrelevant. Soon, they will migrate to the East to experience true European culture. And if East Europeans want to experience Africa or the Middle East, a short trip to any major city in the West will be enough.

The less someone can achieve on his (her) own, the more tempted to need some people to look down at, that is all. And yes, the choice for western Europeans who believe that they built the cathedrals with their own bare hands, is much larger than for any other group. But wait a minute: have you seen any so competent and diligent western European building cathedrals?

yes unfortunately. Racism is everywhere. They are not white enough ? Not European enough, and they immigrat and steal work according to the racist. It’s a never ending story. Even in North Europe ther is racism for south Europeans. The status are Muslims.. ..very scary Color…that’s shady East Europeans …lesser Europeans South Europeans …still to much color. I don’t really understand racism. Judge people from the melanine level in the skin , religions and ethnicity. I’m from Scandinavia, so white I’m almost pink. According to racists , does that mean that albinos and pink people are more valuable? Just wondering. 1 in 10 Europeans support populist far right, USA is no better this time. Good luck to everyone

In France no. There are prejudices coming from ignorance as we were separated during decades by the iron curtain. But nobody really have a bad opinion of central or eastern europeans. We met a lot of easterners as migrants, some became higly valued french figures, even national heroes like Marie Curie. So which kind of simpleton could look down people from countries who offered us such decent countrymen?

Eastern Europeans integrated quite well where in Ireland. Ireland kind of bucks the trend when it comes to western Europe though, we didn't do the whole empire thing so don’t have this period of military superiority and conquest to look back on fondly. We don’t have the same notions of grandeur that the rest of them do. That’s not to say there wasn’t plenty of xenophobia at first, we were a bit taken aback by the influx of people, it had never happened before. We also hadn’t experienced the competition having people willing to work for half the price. People often couldn’t decide whether it was a good thing or a bad thing. Ireland of course have been on the other side of the equation plenty of times ourselves immigrating to American and Britain so we could definitely understand the immigrant position and had to appreciate their willingness to work. Which was certainly taken advantage of by Irish builders. In a way it’s probably a good thing for the integration of those immigrants that Ireland went through a recession. It removed the incentive for more people to come to Ireland and many of the people already here moved on to someplace where they could get work. The ones that stayed settled down here and integrated into communities all over the country. Go to any small town in Ireland today and it’s highly likely there’s at least one eastern European living in the town.
Yes. There is a hierarchy. Germanic Europeans (UK, Germany, Norway, Sweden, etc.)Romance Europeans (French, Spanish, Italian)Celtic Europeans (Irish)Eastern Europeans (Russian, Polish, Serbs, etc.)

Maybe some do, but I don’t know any. Expectations are a little different when going to some east European countries; things don’t always work well. But in general, no. If anything I will respect the last 75 years of survival instinct training more than I would a westener.
